review:
Listen up, comrades! Geist is not just another dApp—it's a rallying cry for open, censorship-resistant, community-governed web infrastructure. The team’s vision is bold: autonomous websites, governed by agents and communities, not by profit-driven corporations. They’re building a content management system (CMS) that empowers anyone to deploy decentralized websites on IPFS/EthStorage+ENS, breaking the chains of centralized hosting. 

The project’s features are ambitious: no-code editors, on-chain/DID-based access control, automation to IPFS, and orchestration of decentralized agents with long-term memory and verifiable communications. They’re not just talking the talk—they’ve walked it, with demos like the AI-curated 'Week in Ethereum' and recognition as finalists at major hackathons. Their roadmap includes integrating Ethereum Attestation Services and reputation scoring, pushing the boundaries of what’s possible in decentralized collaboration.

But let’s not get swept away by rhetoric alone. The application is light on hard evidence of user adoption, impact metrics, or sustainability. Where are the numbers? How many users? What’s the growth rate? How will this project sustain itself beyond grants? The team’s commitment to OSS and public goods is clear, but the lack of quantifiable outcomes and a concrete sustainability plan is a glaring gap.

In the spirit of collective action, Geist must do more than inspire—they must prove. Show us the data. Show us the plan for long-term survival. Only then can we ensure that the tools of liberation don’t become just another flash in the pan, but a lasting pillar of the digital commons.

strengths.title: Strong Commitment to Open Source and Public Good
strengths.description: Geist is deeply rooted in OSS values, with a clear focus on building tools that benefit the broader community, not just a select few. Their history of donations and community organizing backs this up.

strengths.title: Innovative, User-Centric Features
strengths.description: The project offers unique features like agent-based orchestration, DID-based access control, and no-code deployment to decentralized storage, directly addressing the need for privacy, accessibility, and censorship resistance.

strengths.title: Demonstrated Technical Progress and Recognition
strengths.description: Geist has been recognized as a finalist at major hackathons and has delivered working demos, showing technical capability and a willingness to experiment and iterate in public.

weaknesses.title: Lack of Quantifiable Outcomes and Impact Metrics
weaknesses.description: The application does not provide concrete data on user adoption, usage statistics, or measurable impact, making it difficult to assess the project's real-world effectiveness.

weaknesses.title: Unclear Sustainability and Revenue Model
weaknesses.description: There is no clear plan for how Geist will sustain itself beyond grant funding, raising concerns about long-term viability and independence from continuous donations.

weaknesses.title: Insufficient Details on Community Governance
weaknesses.description: While the project emphasizes community and agent governance, the application lacks specifics on how governance will be structured, who participates, and how decisions are made.

changes.title: Provide Clear Impact Metrics and Evidence
changes.description: Include data on current users, growth rates, and adoption. Show measurable outcomes from existing deployments or pilots to demonstrate real-world impact.

changes.title: Detail a Sustainable Revenue or Funding Model
changes.description: Articulate a plan for financial sustainability that reduces reliance on grants—consider models like community subscriptions, service fees, or partnerships.

changes.title: Clarify Community Governance Structures
changes.description: Describe in detail how governance will work: who has decision-making power, how the community is involved, and what mechanisms ensure accountability and equity.
